fields.title: Atlantic Sturgeon - Saint John River Population
fields.file: CSAM21 -Atlantic Sturgeon Saint John River request 2021-22.pdf
fields.issue:
For the Saint John River Atlantic Sturgeon spawning population (COSEWIC assessed as "threatened"):
(1) provide an estimate of the current spawning stock biomass as well as advice on appropriate reference points;
(2) provide advice as to whether the current 350 fish commercial quota (175 males and 175 females) is appropriate relative to the information provided in answer to question (1); and
(3) provide advice as to the usefulness and appropriateness of the current annual closure (month of June) to protect spawning adults, i.e., does the closure provide benefits and is it of the appropriate duration and at the appropriate time of year.
fields.consequence_text: Atlantic sturgeon is under consideration for listing under SARA and a regional recommendation was submitted to NHQ in 2016. The commitment to submit requests for the Science advice considered necessary for improving the management of the Atlantic sturgeon fishery was part of this recommendation. A request for CSAS advice was submitted for 2017/18,but has not move forward to date. It is anticipated that a listing decision will be published within the next 2 years so there is a need for the region to demonstrate progress towards more effective management of the fishery.  Additionally, erroneous food, social and ceremonial allocations to Aboriginal organizations, erroneous quota allocations in the commercial fishery and the loss of recreational access could result from the lack of Science advice.
fields.rationale:
The advice will be used to provide Aboriginal organizations, commercial and recreational stakeholders, Province of NB and DFO information on the status of the Atlantic sturgeon spawning population for the Saint John River (Maritimes DU) that will guide fisheries management decisions.

Furthermore, it is anticipated that a SARA listing decision could be made within the next 2 years. Maritimes Region has submitted a recommendation to not list the species under SARA and, as required under the Department’s “Do Not List Directive”, has prepared a 5 year workplan outlining the alternate approach that will be used to manage the species and its threats. The Science advice requested is required to fulfill, in part, the Department’s commitments under the workplan should the regional recommendation be accepted as the DFO's position on listing.  

This information will also be used to support changes to, or maintenance of, the current terminal licence policy in the commercial fishery.
fields.rationale_for_timing: The 2021 commercial sturgeon fishery will resume in May, 2021 under the same quota and close times that were in place in 2017 in the absence of any updated Science advice that might point to the use of more effective management measures for this population.
